text:
EPR:
Patient, a 55-year-old male, was admitted with complaints of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and associated shortness of breath.
On examination, the patient appeared diaphoretic with blood pressure elevated at 160/90 mmHg, heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.
Initial ECG revealed sinus tachycardia with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels were elevated, suggestive of acute myocardial infarction.
The patient was promptly started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and intravenous nitroglycerin. Cardiology consultation requested for further management and possible catheterization.

EPR:
Follow-up note for a 65-year-old female with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Blood glucose levels have been well-controlled with recent HbA1c within the target range.
Medication reconciliation performed, and adjustments made to the insulin regimen to optimize glycemic control.
Patient educated on the importance of regular blood glucose monitoring, proper diet, and exercise.
Follow-up appointment scheduled in 3 months for continued management.

EPR:
Emergency department note for a 40-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident.
The patient was brought in by ambulance with complaints of severe right leg pain.
Physical examination revealed tenderness and swelling over the right femur.
CT scan of the pelvis and femur confirmed a displaced fracture of the right femoral shaft.
Orthopedic surgery consulted for further evaluation and management.
The patient was given analgesia and placed in traction pending surgical intervention.

EPR:
Psychiatric evaluation for a 30-year-old female presenting with symptoms of depression.
The patient reports a persistent low mood, loss of interest in activities, poor appetite, and difficulty sleeping.
No significant suicidal ideation reported.
Past psychiatric history includes a previous episode of major depressive disorder.
Started the patient on sertraline and provided psychoeducation on coping strategies.
Referral made to a therapist for ongoing support.

EPR:
Consultation note for a 25-year-old male admitted with severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain.
Physical examination consistent with suspected appendicitis.
Laboratory results showed an elevated white blood cell count.
CT abdomen and pelvis ordered, revealing acute appendicitis with localized abscess formation.
The patient placed on NPO status, started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and surgical intervention scheduled for appendectomy.

EPR:
Admission note for a 45-year-old female presenting with acute respiratory distress.
History reveals a recent upper respiratory tract infection.
On examination, the patient is tachypneic with bilateral crackles on auscultation.
Chest X-ray shows diffuse infiltrates consistent with viral pneumonia.
Oxygen supplementation initiated, and antiviral therapy prescribed.
Close monitoring for respiratory status ongoing.

EPR:
Follow-up note for a 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension.
Blood pressure well-controlled on current medication regimen.
Discussion on lifestyle modifications, including a low-sodium diet and regular exercise.
Patient advised on the importance of regular follow-up appointments for ongoing blood pressure management.

EPR:
Emergency department note for a 35-year-old female involved in a fall from a height.
Complaints of back pain and numbness in both lower extremities.
Neurological examination indicates sensory deficits.
CT spine ordered, revealing a thoracic spine fracture.
Neurosurgery consultation requested for further evaluation and management.

EPR:
Psychiatric evaluation for a 28-year-old male with symptoms of anxiety and panic attacks.
The patient reports palpitations, sweating, and a sense of impending doom during episodes.
No significant past psychiatric history.
Started on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and referred for cognitive-behavioral therapy.

EPR:
Consultation note for a 50-year-old female with abdominal pain and distension.
Physical examination consistent with ascites.
Paracentesis performed, revealing elevated white cell count and protein levels.
Further workup initiated for the underlying cause of ascites.
Gastroenterology consultation requested for comprehensive evaluation.

EPR:
Admission note for a 22-year-old male presenting with a seizure episode.
No prior history of seizures reported. Neurological examination unremarkable.
CT scan of the brain performed, showing no acute abnormalities.
The patient started on antiepileptic medication, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) scheduled for further evaluation.

EPR:
Follow-up note for a 70-year-old female with a history of congestive heart failure.
Recent exacerbation managed with diuretic adjustment and oxygen therapy.
Patient educated on sodium restriction and fluid management.
Close outpatient follow-up scheduled to monitor symptoms and optimize heart failure management.

EPR:
Emergency department note for a 40-year-old male with a laceration to the right hand from a work-related injury.
Wound cleaned and sutured. Tetanus prophylaxis administered.
Occupational health referral made for further assessment and follow-up.

EPR:
Psychiatric evaluation for a 25-year-old female presenting with symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) following a recent traumatic event.
The patient experiences intrusive thoughts and nightmares.
Started on a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) and referred for trauma-focused therapy.

EPR:
Consultation note for a 55-year-old male with persistent epigastric pain.
Upper endoscopy performed, revealing erosive gastritis.
Proton pump inhibitor prescribed, and lifestyle modifications discussed.
Gastroenterology follow-up recommended for ongoing management.

EPR:
Admission note for a 38-year-old female presenting with a mysterious neurological syndrome.
The patient experiences sudden and transient episodes of total paralysis, lasting a few minutes.
Extensive neurological workup initiated, including genetic testing for a rare hereditary paralysis disorder.
Neurology and genetics consultations requested for further evaluation.

EPR:
Follow-up note for a 45-year-old male with a history of unexplained fevers and skin lesions resembling butterfly wings.
Extensive infectious disease and rheumatological workup inconclusive.
Immunology and dermatology consultations ongoing to explore the possibility of a novel autoimmune disorder.

EPR:
Emergency department note for a 28-year-old male presenting with acute respiratory distress and bizarre neuropsychiatric symptoms.
Preliminary investigations inconclusive.
Suspected rare autoimmune encephalitis with respiratory involvement.
Immunotherapy initiated, and neurology and pulmonology consulted for collaborative management.

EPR:
Psychiatric evaluation for a 32-year-old female with sudden-onset obsessive-compulsive behaviors, including a compulsion to count objects in prime numbers.
No history of psychiatric illness.
Neurology and psychiatry consultations in progress for consideration of a rare neurodevelopmental disorder.

EPR:
Consultation note for a 50-year-old male with chronic abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding. 
nitial investigations inconclusive.
Gastroenterology and hematology consulted for further evaluation of a suspected rare vascular malformation disorder affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
